name: 2.Data Description and Preparation
content:
Data Description:

This dataset corresponds to XYZ Bank's direct marketing campaign, predominantly utilizing telephone calls. Multiple contacts with the same client were made to determine their subscription preference ('yes' or 'no') for a term deposit. The classification goal is to predict customer sign-up (yes/no) for a term deposit (variable y). The dataset comprises 20 entries/columns, spanning from May 2008 to November 2010. The key features are

  • Age: Numeric
  • Job: Type of job (Categorical)
  • Marital: Marital status (Categorical)
  • Education: Education level (Categorical)
  • Default: Has credit in default? (Categorical)
  • Housing: Has a housing loan? (Categorical)
  • Loan: Has a personal loan? (Categorical)
  • Contact: Contact communication type (Categorical)
  • Month: Last contact month of the year (Categorical)
  • Day_of_week: Last contact day of the week (Categorical)
  • Duration: Last contact duration, in seconds (Numeric)
  • Campaign: Number of contacts performed during this campaign and for this client (Numeric, includes the last contact)
  • Pdays: Number of days that passed by after the client was last contacted from a previous campaign (Numeric; 999 means the client was not previously contacted)
  • Previous: Number of contacts performed before this campaign and for this client (Numeric)
  • Poutcome: Outcome of the previous marketing campaign (Categorical)
  • Emp.var.rate: Employment variation rate - quarterly indicator (Numeric)
  • Cons.price.idx: Consumer price index - monthly indicator (Numeric)
  • Cons.conf.idx: Consumer confidence index - monthly indicator (Numeric)
  • Euribor3m: Euribor 3-month rate - daily indicator (Numeric)
  • Nr.employed: Number of employees - quarterly indicator (Numeric)


Data Preparation:

  • Handling Null Values in 'Nr.employed':

The 'Nr.employed' feature exhibits a substantial 80% presence of null values. To ensure data integrity and avoid potential biases, we opt to remove this specific feature from our dataset.

  • Categorizing 'Age' into Age Groups:

To enhance the interpretability of the 'age' feature, we introduce a categorical transformation. We divide the age range into four distinct categories or groups, facilitating a more insightful analysis of age-related patterns in the data.

  • Scaling 'Pdays' for Binary Representation:

For the 'Pdays' feature, we implement a scaling strategy to convert it into a binary representation. Values of 999, signifying that a client was not previously contacted, are mapped to 0. All other values are mapped to 1, indicating contact in a previous marketing campaign. This binary representation simplifies the interpretation of the 'Pdays' feature, making it more amenable to modeling and analysis.
